message_1:
A class of 30 students took a math test and received the following scores:

70, 72, 75, 78, 80, 82, 84, 86, 88, 90, 92, 94, 96, 98, 99, 99, 99, 99, 99, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 150

Using outlier detection techniques, determine the outlier(s) in the data set and explain why they are considered outliers.
message_2:
To detect outliers, we can use the Interquartile Range (IQR) method. First, we need to find the first quartile (Q1), the second quartile (Q2, also known as the median), and the third quartile (Q3) of the data set. Then, we calculate the IQR and use it to determine the lower and upper bounds for outliers.

Step 1: Arrange the data in ascending order:
70, 72, 75, 78, 80, 82, 84, 86, 88, 90, 92, 94, 96, 98, 99, 99, 99, 99, 99, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 150

Step 2: Find Q1, Q2, and Q3:
Q1 (25th percentile) is the median of the first half of the data: (80+82)/2 = 81
Q2 (50th percentile) is the median of the entire data set: (92+94)/2 = 93
Q3 (75th percentile) is the median of the second half of the data: (100+100)/2 = 100

Step 3: Calculate the IQR:
IQR = Q3 - Q1 = 100 - 81 = 19

Step 4: Determine the lower and upper bounds for outliers:
Lower bound = Q1 - 1.5 * IQR = 81 - 1.5 * 19 = 52.5
Upper bound = Q3 + 1.5 * IQR = 100 + 1.5 * 19 = 128.5

Step 5: Identify the outliers:
Any data point below the lower bound or above the upper bound is considered an outlier. In this case, the only outlier is 150, as it is greater than the upper bound of 128.5.

The score of 150 is considered an outlier because it is significantly higher than the majority of the scores in the data set and falls outside the range defined by the IQR method. This could indicate an error in data collection or an unusually high performance by one student compared to the rest of the class.
